titleproper.value:
Guide to the William Morris Letters
                    <num>TAM.420</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Peter Meyer Filardo

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2012-03-29T19:40-0400</date>

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: William Morris (1834-1896) was a British socialist, poet, artist and architect, and leading figure in the Arts and Crafts movement. Contains signed letters by Morris. Recipients include John Coleman Kenworthy and Theodore Watts-Dunton. Also included is a copy of an 1855 letter from Morris to his mother, Emma Morris.

p.value:
Published citations should take the following form: 
                <lb/>
                <lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; 
                <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives 
                <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library 
                <lb/>70 Washington Square South 
                <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

<list>
                    <item>Derived from: International Institute for Social History Archives http://www.iisg.nl/archives/morris/</item>
                    <item>See also: William Morris Society http://www.morrissociety.org/</item>
                    <item>See also: William Morris Internet Archive (includes chronology) http://www.marxists.org/archive/morris/</item>
                </list>

The collection contains eleven handwritten letters signed by Morris, a handwritten copy of an 1855 letter from Morris to his mother, Emma Morris, with an accompanying letter of transmittal and envelope. Six letters are to John Coleman Kenworthy, 1863-1948, a younger socialist then living in Liverpool. There are single letters to Charles Augustus Howell (1840-1890); ("I return Rossetti letter...") to poet, author and critic, Theodore Watts-Dunton (re: a manuscript of 
                <title render="italic">The Coming of Love</title>, 1898), and three letters to unidentified recipients. All the items have been encapsulated, except for the copy of the letter to Morris’s mother.

                        <unittitle>William Morris to: Kenworthy, [John Coleman] 
                            <lb/>Contents: six letters, one undated. Concern trips by Morris to Liverpool, where Kenworthy apparently lived, possible meetings in London, and [upon Kenworthy's return from a trip to America] Morris' aversion to the idea of traveling to America.</unittitle>
                        <container id="cid105409" type="Box" label="Mixed materials">1</container>
                        <container parent="cid105409" type="Folder">2</container>

                            <lb/>Contents: "Copy of a letter from William Morris to his Mother" [Exeter Coll. Oxon., Nov 11th, 1855]; a letter to Sara Anderson, Nov 17, 1897, from "Catie" [?], the copier of Morris's 1855 letter; and the envelope addressed to Miss Anderson</unittitle>
                        <container id="cid105408" type="Box" label="Mixed materials">1</container>
                        <container parent="cid105408" type="Folder">3</container>
                        <unitdate normal="1866/1897" type="inclusive">undated ; Nov 17, 1897</unitdate>
